Oddly, though, this last detail didn't seem to bother her much. It felt almost natural, somehow.

But, first, she said. I've really got to get something to eat! She rushed to the kitchen.

Betty opened the fridge and found it fully stocked. In fact, it was stuffed full, there was barely room to close the door. Betty opened all the cupboards and found them similarly jam packed. Odd, she thought. Who would pack so much food in here and why. But her stomach rumbled again, remind her that she had more immediate concerns. Betty quickly dove into the fridge. She pulled out a pear and practically devoured.

It wrapped itself around a ham and pulled it into Betty's mouth. Before the girl realized what was happening she had swallowed it whole. Betty boggled at what she had just done. Ok, she said. I admit it's way more efficient, if a little gross. Her stomach rumbled again. Nevermind, she thought. I can be grossed out by it later.

Betty dove into the fridge with a passion. Several minutes later, two thirds of the fridge was gone and Betty felt stuffed. Ugh, she grunted. I hope I don't make a habit of that, the food bills are going to go through the roof. Now, to find out what's going on. Betty tried the phone, but there was no dial tone. It figures, she thought. She turned on the tv. Fortunately, it was working, but it just keep repeating an emergency broadcast. A reporter was frantically warning people about some type of creature seen in the area and warning people to stay in their homes. That has to be mom, Betty thought. I've definitely got to try to find her. She looked down at herself. And try not to get shot, or captured myself in the process. Suddenly, Betty heard another gurgling sound.

Oh come on, Betty griped. I ate enough food to feed a girl scout troop. I can be hungry again already...ugh! Suddenly, a sharp cramp ran through her midsection. Betty toppled to the floor, clutching her stomach. Ok, maybe I over did it a little. She managed to get to her hands and knees, but the cramp was replaced by a squirming sensation. It felt as though something were moving around inside of her.

Suddenly, there was a loud sqeulching noise directly behind her. Betty was almost afraid to look, but turned anyway. Something was sitting on the carpet behind her. It was made out of some blue, jelly-like material and looked distressingly egg shaped. Oh, please tell me that isn't what I think it is! Betty moaned. This day is insane enough as it is without...errgh! Betty's thought was cut off by more cramps and squirming feelings. By the time it was over, twelve blue things sat on the carpet. It was as though someone had arranged a dozen jello molds in a neat pile.

Great, Betty fumed. This is just what I need right now. That's it, I'm contacting Admiral DeGill. She walked up to her room. And started looking around. They had had swim practice at school that day, or whenever that day had been. After a previous incident, Betty had wisely decided to leave her communicator home. Now where did I put that? She pondered. Aha, there you are. Betty pulled the watch from the bottom of one of her drawers. Now then, she said. To get some answers.

She was about to activate the communicator, when her much more sensative ears picked up a sound coming from downstairs.. Oh, now what? She fumed. Cautiously moving downstairs, Betty traced the sound back to the living round. The egg-things were quivering violently. Betty gulped, as creature slowly emerged from the eggs. Betty was astonished that the creatures look like her. Ok, they looked like her, if she looked like an alien creature with claws and aentennai, which, she reminded herself, she now did.

Aw, Betty said. That's actually kind of cute, in a freaky sort of way. Just then, a whimpering sound caught Betty's attention. She looked over. One of the creatures wasn't moving towards her, it was just laying. Oh no, she thought, something must be wrong with it. Betty walked over to the creature and got a closer look. It was smaller than the others, though it seemed to be having trouble. Oh, poor thing, Betty thought, let me help you out. Betty picked the creature up and began cuddling it. The creature purred in her arms. It opened it's eyes and looked up at her.

She looked down at her, children, or whatever they were and sighed. Ok, she said. We're definitely going to have to cover table manners.

A few minutes passed and the kitchen was emptied of food. The creatures seemed satisfied, but Betty looked around and sighed. I don't have a choice now, she said. I'm definitely going to have to go out and find some more food. She quickly left a message for Admiral DeGill to get back to her as soon he could, before leading the way to the living room. The creatures followed behind her, now walking upright. Though the little one was content to cling to Betty's shoulders and hitch a ride.

Betty approached the front door. She wrapped her hand around the handle. Well, she said. Here goes nothing. Before she could stop to think about it, Betty flung the door open wide.
